title: The Story of Vajrakumär
subtitle: Section I.1 from JAB Manual 5th edition 2024

storyContent.tagHTML: In the city of Tumbivan, a rich Brahmin named Dhangiri and his beautiful wife Sunandä lived a joyful life. When Sunandä became pregnant, she had a wonderful dream that her husband, a scholar, said meant she would have a bright and charming child.

One day, a Jain Ächärya named Singhiri arrived. His sermons deeply moved Dhangiri, who lost interest in worldly life and decided to become a monk. Despite his wife's shock and pleas to stay for their coming child, Dhangiri's mind was made up. He made financial arrangements for his family, and Sunandä, understanding religion deeply, accepted his decision.

A few months later, Sunandä gave birth to a handsome, smiling boy. But her happiness was short-lived. One day, a neighbor remarked how much more extravagantly Dhangiri would have celebrated the birth if he hadn't taken Dikshä.

The baby heard the word "Dikshä" and suddenly remembered his past life. He realized he was on a spiritual path and decided he must become a monk like his father. Knowing his mother wouldn't let him go, he devised a plan: he would cry constantly until she got tired of him. His plan worked perfectly. The constant crying exhausted his mother and the neighbors.

When the child was six months old, his father, now Muni Dhangiri, visited the city with Ächärya Singhiri. Fed up, Sunandä decided to give the child to his father. The Ächärya, who had special powers, had already told Muni Dhangiri to accept any "live thing" offered as alms that day.

When Muni Dhangiri arrived at his old home for alms, the baby started crying loudly. Sunandä, at her wit's end, begged him, "Please accept him so there will be peace in this house." Muni Dhangiri warned her, "Once you give him away, you will not be able to get him back." But she insisted.

She placed the child in the muni's cloth bag. Instantly, the boy stopped crying and started smiling. Surprised but determined, Sunandä watched them leave. At the Upäshray, the Ächärya saw the heavy bag and the handsome, smiling boy inside. Because he was so heavy, the Ächärya named him "Vajrakumär." He was given to a prominent Jain family to be raised with religious teachings.

Vajrakumär was a brilliant child. By age three, he had memorized eleven Anga Ägams. One day, a friend told Sunandä how lovable and happy her son was. Her motherly love returned, and she deeply regretted her decision.

Sunandä went to get her son back, but the monks refused. Desperate, she appealed to the king. The king, after hearing the full story, arranged a test in his courthouse. He told Sunandä, "I will let Vajrakumär decide whom he wants to go with."

The next day, the court was full. Sunandä brought toys, sweets, and clothes to tempt her son. On the other side, Muni Dhangiri had only an Ogho (a monk's broom). The king explained the choice to Vajrakumär. The young boy looked at his mother's gifts, then at his father's broom. He walked over, picked up the Ogho, and began to dance with joy.
Everyone was amazed. Sunandä accepted his decision, and Vajrakumär's Dikshä was celebrated with joy. He later became a great Ächärya.

events.title: Dhangiri's Life
events.description: A rich Brahmin named Dhangiri lived happily with his wife Sunandä in the city of Tumbivan.

events.title: Spiritual Awakening
events.description: Dhangiri and Sunandä listen to sermons from Ächärya Singhiri, which awakens Dhangiri's soul and makes him decide to become a monk.

events.title: Dhangiri Takes Dikshä
events.description: Despite Sunandä being pregnant, Dhangiri renounces his worldly life to become a monk, after making financial arrangements for his family.

events.title: Birth of Vajrakumär
events.description: Sunandä gives birth to a very handsome and lovable boy.

events.title: Past Life Remembrance
events.description: As a baby, hearing the word 'Dikshä' triggers a memory of his past life, and he decides he must also become a monk.

events.title: The Crying Plan
events.description: Realizing his mother won't let him go, he decides to cry incessantly to make her give him up.

events.title: Offered as Alms
events.description: Fed up with the crying, Sunandä offers her son as alms to his father, Muni Dhangiri, when he visits.

events.title: Accepted by Father
events.description: Remembering his guru's words, Muni Dhangiri accepts the child after warning Sunandä of the finality of her decision.

events.title: Named Vajrakumär
events.description: The baby stops crying instantly. At the Upäshray, Ächärya Singhiri names him 'Vajrakumär' because he was so heavy.

events.title: Raised by Shrävak
events.description: He is placed in the care of a prominent Jain shrävak to be taught religious teachings, and he learns the eleven Anga Ägams by age three.

timelineData.era: The Mother's Regret and The King's Court

events.title: Sunandä's Regret
events.description: Sunandä learns her son is a charming and happy child and desperately wants him back.

events.title: Appeal to the King
events.description: After the monks refuse to return him, Sunandä goes to the king for help.

events.title: The King's Decision
events.description: The king decides to let Vajrakumär choose his own path in a courthouse assembly.

events.title: The Final Choice
events.description: In court, presented with his mother's toys and his father's Ogho (broom), Vajrakumär joyfully chooses the Ogho, signifying his desire for monkhood.

charactersData.name: Vajrakumär
charactersData.description: The central character, born as a Brahmin who remembers his past life and chooses the path of a monk from infancy.

charactersData.name: Dhangiri
charactersData.description: Vajrakumär's father, a rich Brahmin who becomes a Jain monk (Muni Dhangiri) after being inspired by sermons.

charactersData.name: Sunandä
charactersData.description: Vajrakumär's mother, who initially gives him away due to his crying but later regrets it and tries to get him back.

charactersData.name: Ächärya Singhiri
charactersData.description: The Jain Ächärya whose sermons inspire Dhangiri and who names the baby Vajrakumär.

charactersData.name: The King
charactersData.description: The ruler of Tumbivan who is asked to mediate the dispute and wisely decides to let Vajrakumär choose his own destiny.

charactersData.name: Jain Shrävak & his wife
charactersData.description: The devout Jain family that raises Vajrakumär after he is given away, ensuring he receives religious education.

quizData.question: What was the name of Vajrakumär's father?
Who was the Jain Ächärya that inspired Dhangiri to become a monk?
What did Vajrakumär do to convince his mother to give him away?
How old was Vajrakumär when his mother gave him to his father?
Why did Ächärya Singhiri name the baby 'Vajrakumär'?
quizData.answer: Because he was very heavy ('Vajra' implies strength/heaviness).

quizData.question: How many Anga Ägams had Vajrakumär learned by the age of three?
Who did Sunandä go to for help to get her son back?
What two choices was Vajrakumär presented with in the king's court?
quizData.answer: His mother's toys/sweets and his father's Ogho (monk's broom).

quizData.question: What item did Vajrakumär choose in the courthouse?
What did Sunandä do after Vajrakumär made his choice?
quizData.answer: She accepted his decision and celebrated his Dikshä (initiation as a monk).

children.name: Given away as alms at 6 months

graphicsData.title: The Divine Plan
graphicsData.description: Remembering his past life, the infant Vajrakumär knows he must become a monk. He decides to cry constantly so his mother will let him go.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Baby Vajrakumär crying loudly in his crib.

graphicsData.title: A Mother's Plea
graphicsData.description: Exhausted, Sunandä offers her crying child as alms to his father, Muni Dhangiri.
graphicsData.dialogue: Sunandä: "Please accept him so there will be peace in this house!"
graphicsData.imageAlt: A tired Sunandä hands her baby to Muni Dhangiri.

graphicsData.title: A Sudden Change
graphicsData.description: As soon as he is in his father's arms, the baby stops crying and smiles, revealing his true nature. Sunandä is stunned.
graphicsData.imageAlt: The baby instantly stops crying and smiles at his father, the monk.

graphicsData.title: The Appeal
graphicsData.description: Years later, Sunandä learns her son is a happy, brilliant child and desperately wants him back. She goes to the king for help.
graphicsData.dialogue: Sunandä: "Please, help me get my son back. I cannot live without him."
graphicsData.imageAlt: A regretful Sunandä pleads her case before the king on his throne.

graphicsData.title: The Courthouse Test
graphicsData.description: The king lets Vajrakumär choose his destiny. He ignores the toys and sweets from his mother and joyfully picks up the monk's simple broom.
graphicsData.imageAlt: In the courthouse, young Vajrakumär turns away from toys and reaches for the monk's broom (Ogho).

graphicsData.title: A Great Teacher
graphicsData.description: Having chosen his path, Vajrakumär's Dikshä is celebrated. He fulfills his destiny and becomes a great and respected Ächärya.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A wise and serene Ächärya Vajrakumär teaching his followers.
